clinical_study.brief_title: Sit-to-stand With Feedback in SCI Patients
clinical_study.official_title: The Provision of External Feedback During Sit-to-stand in Ambulatory Patients With Spinal Cord Injury

brief_summary.textblock:
- Does the utility of external feedback in terms of goal-directed LLL approach during STS training immediately improve functional ability relating to walking in ambulatory patients with SCI?
- Does the utility of LLL feedback improve functional ability relating to walking in ambulatory patients with SCI after 2-week training?

detailed_description.textblock:
- To compare immediate effects of STS training with and without LLL feedback on functional ability relating to walking in ambulatory patients with SCI
- To compare 2 weeks effects of STS training with and without LLL feedback on functional ability relating to walking in ambulatory patients with SCI.

arm_group.description: Subjects will be trained using the sit-to-stand weight-taking machine. Prior to the training, subjects sit in a standard sitting position. Then they will be instructed to take most of their body-weight onto the legs while they standing up where the light bars will be gradually lightened from the red, yellow and green zones according to the level of LLL. Then they stand up, hold a standing position for 3-5 seconds and sit-down with always maximize their body-weight onto their legs during performing the task in which the green zone will always be lightened.
Subjects will be trained using the same instruction and protocol as the experimental group, but without the provision of external feedback.

intervention.description: Sit to stand training with external feedback

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Ambulatory spinal cord injury patients
Exclusion Criteria:
- Deformity of musculoskeletal system
